title_sort: william e. vandemark to walt whitman 7 december 1863
title: William E. Vandemark to Walt Whitman 7 December 1863
text: Dear FatherI have wrten[written] to yo some time a go and have not had answer as yet i[I] donte[don't] know wat[what] to think some times i[I] think that yo have not received the letter Â I hope wen[when] those few lines reach you they will find yo well i[I] am quite well my hip hurts me some friday[Friday] i[I] was exazamend[examined] by the beast of dockters[doctors] i[I] would not go in the invalid corps so they send me to my ridgement[regiment] i[I] am willing to go and try and do my duty thair[there] and if the Rebs hit me a gen[again] all rite[right] i[I] will take up with itthe wether[weather] is quite cold here now and we had a bout two inches snow here i[I] suppose that i[I] will be in elickzander[Alexandria] [Alexandria] they cant put me in the invalid corps i[I] think thair[there] is to much humbug thair[there] i[I] have ben[been] home sence[since] i[I] left Washington i[I] wish yo would see dockter[doctor] blis[bliss] and have him to send my discriptive[descriptive] list to the sargent[sergeant] in charge for i[I] hante[haven't] ben[been] paid in very neer[near] six month and cant get paid without the discriptive[descriptive] list he will direct it to Dockter[Doctor] Smith, Sargent in charge Decam general-hospittle[general-hospital] Davids Island N Y Hpleas[Please] write and let me know how yo are geting[getting] a long and how the boys is gets a long tel[tell] them i[I] am going to my ridgment[regiment] agen[again] i[I] like the place very well thair[there] is 22 pavilions and they are bilding[building] all the time and a nice Church here and then other fixtures such as headquarters and the like of the church is the St pauls[Paul's] docktren[doctrine] to day was communeion[communion] i[I] was up to see the site of corse[course]well father we have had some splendid vicktorys[victories] and it maks[makes] me feel that i[I] have confidence yet and hope that day will not be fare off we peace will be in our land once more may god grant us the blesing[blessing] of a spedy[speedy] peace at the same time not give the Rebs an inch of ground for war here after for father to think the lives that has ben[been] lost in this war[where] i[I] suppose that god knows best in all things father i[I] long to see yo and have good talk to yo a grate meny[many] of the boys have gone to bedlous island but they will hardly leave thair[there] this winter thair[there] is lots of virmen[vermin] that here they are hard cases i[I] thinkwell father i[I] will hef[have] to close now good by from Wm E Vandemark to his friend Walt Whitman please write William E. Vandemark to Walt Whitman 7 December 1863
